Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Yinkun Li is "Harmonic Maass Forms of Weight One and Arithmetic Intersection." The host institution for the fellowship is the Technical University of Darmstadt, Germany, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Jan Bruinier.

This award was supported with funding from the Office of International and Integrative Activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we studied real-dihedral harmonic Maass forms, which are certain real-analytic modular forms of weight 1, whose images under a certain first order differential operator are classical holomorphic cusp forms of weight 1 constructed from real quadratic fields by Hecke in 1927. We modified this construction, which is a theta integral, by considering its first order deformation. This enabled us to produce explicitly harmonic Maass forms of weight one, whose holomorphic part Fourier coefficients are logarithms of algebraic numbers.

Later, we applied the theta lift machinery to this harmonic Maass form and were able to express the CM-values of higher Green's functions in terms of these Fourier coefficients. From this, we proved a conjecture concerning the algebraicity of the special values of higher Green's functions on product of modular curves. Furthermore, we gave explicit factorizations of these algebraic values produced by the higher Green's functions. 

Finally, using CM-values of higher Green's functions, we were able to prove some new results about singular moduli, which are the values of the modular j-invariant at CM points and are algebraic integers. Recently, it was proved that singular modulus can never be a unit. Using the factorization of the norm of the difference of singular moduli, and its generalization to higher Green's functions, we gave a different proof of this result, and generalized it to the difference of two singular moduli.
